prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum imaging at 0.2" resolution in Band-7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We target 4 galaxies at z~1.47 from the UDS field. Sources have been already imaged with VLT/SINFONI (AO-aided) at a resolution of 0.2" in Halpha. We aim to use ALMA Band-7 observations to describe the continuum dust emission at matched resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We checked that the only observable high-J CO transition at z=1.47 is CO(6-5). If we aim to target the same rest frequency than the other science goals, we loose considerable power on the continuum due to the Rayleigh Jeans regime on the SED. For this reason we decided to use the optimised default continuum setup in Band-7.

We request 0.2" resolution to match the available IFU-AO imaging. Based on thedistribution of the ionised gas traced by tHalpha imaging, sources are much smaller than the field of view in Band-7. Single pointing observations are sufficient. No special remarks.

We propose to use Band-7 to observe a sample of H-alpha emitters which have been already imaged with IFU-AO at ~0.2" resolution. We propose matched resolution imaging to describe the H-alpha extinction, and to provide a resolved SFR estimate using two gold standard tracers (H-alpha and far-IR). These observations are key to describe the ongoing star-formation in these distant galaxies.
SENSITIVITY
All targets in this science goal are at redshift z~1.47. We expect to measure continuum flux densities of ~0.8mJy at 870um (345GHz; Band-7). This estimate is obtained by stacking the HiZELS H-alpha population using Spitzer (24 & 70um), Herschel (100, 160, 250, 350 & 500um) and AzTEC (1100um) imaging (Ibar et al. 2013, MNRAS, 343, 3218) -- see figure in the appended science case.
There is no prior morphological information in the far-IR/sub-mm for the targets. Based on the extension and clumpiness of the Halpha imaging, we consider the sources would be imaged with 6 beams in average, i.e. with continuum peaks of ~133um/beam. We aim to reach an rms = 27um/beam in order to image all 6 components at a ~5-sigma significance.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum imaging at 0.2" resolution in Band-6 (1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We target 2 galaxies at z~2.23 from the UDS field. Sources have been already imaged with Gemini-N/NIFS (AO-aided) at a resolution of 0.2" in Halpha. We aim to use ALMA Band-7 observations to describe the continuum dust emission at matched resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In this spectral setup we do not expect any CO or bright line emission within the spectral windows.

We request 0.2" resolution to match the available IFU-AO imaging. Based on the entension of the ionised gas traced by the Halpha imaging, sources are much smaller than the field of view in Band-6. Single pointing observations are sufficient. No special remarks.

We propose to use Band-6 to observe a sample of H-alpha emitters which have been already imaged with IFU-AO at ~0.2" resolution. We propose matched resolution imaging to describe the H-alpha extinction, and to provide a resolved SFR estimate using two gold standard tracers (H-alpha and far-IR). These observations are key to describe the ongoing star-formation in these distant galaxies.
SENSITIVITY:
All targets in this science goal are at redshift z~2.23. We expect to measure continuum flux densities of ~0.8mJy at 870um (345GHz; Band-7). This estimate is obtained by stacking the HiZELS H-alpha population using Herschel (250, 350 & 500um) imaging. Flux densities are similar to those found for the z=1.47 population (Ibar et al. 2013, MNRAS, 343, 3218) -- see figure in the appended science case.
There is no prior morphological information in the far-IR/sub-mm for the targets. Based on the extension and clumpiness of the Halpha imaging, we consider the sources would be imaged with 6 beams in average, i.e. with continuum peaks of ~133um/beam. We aim to reach an rms = 27um/beam in order to image all 6 components at a ~5-sigma significance.

We have changed the default continuum setup in Band-6 in order to observe rest-frame frequencies at 843GHz. This is performed to have a 1:1 comparison with respect to the Band-7 observations of sources at z~1.47.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum imaging at 0.2" resolution in Band-6 (2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We target 2 galaxies at z~2.23 from the COSMOS field. One of the sources have been already imaged with VLT/SINFONI and the other with Gemini-N/NIFS (both AO-aided) at a resolution of 0.2" in Halpha. We aim to use ALMA Band-7 observations to describe the continuum dust emission at matched resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In this spectral setup we do not expect any CO or bright line emission within the spectral windows.

We request 0.2" resolution to match the available IFU-AO imaging. Based on the extension of the ionised gas traced by the Halpha emission, sources are much smaller than the field of view in Band-6. Single pointing observations are sufficient. No special remarks.

We propose to use Band-6 to observe a sample of H-alpha emitters which have been already imaged with IFU-AO at ~0.2" resolution. We propose matched resolution imaging to describe the H-alpha extinction, and to provide a resolved SFR estimate using two gold standard tracers (H-alpha and far-IR). These observations are key to describe the ongoing star-formation in these distant galaxies.
SENSITIVITY:
All targets in this science goal are at redshift z~2.23. We expect to measure continuum flux densities of ~0.8mJy at 870um (345GHz; Band-7). This estimate is obtained by stacking the HiZELS H-alpha population using Herschel (250, 350 & 500um) imaging. Flux densities are similar to those found for the z=1.47 population (Ibar et al. 2013, MNRAS, 343, 3218) -- see figure in the appended science case.
There is no prior morphological information in the far-IR/sub-mm for the targets. Based on the extension and clumpiness of the Halpha imaging, we consider the sources would be imaged with 6 beams in average, i.e. with continuum peaks of ~133um/beam. We aim to reach an rms = 27um/beam in order to image all 6 components at a ~5-sigma significance.

We have changed the default continuum setup in Band-6 in order to observe rest-frame frequencies at 843GHz. This is performed to have a 1:1 comparison with respect to the Band-7 observations of sources at z~1.47.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: This re-submitted proposal (approved but not observed in Cycle-2) aims to obtain spatially resolved imaging of the dust content in 8 high-z Halpha galaxies taken in two redshift slides, z=1.47 & 2.23 of the HiZELS survey. The targets have been observed with VLT/SINFONI and Gemini-N/NIFS, both AO-aided, up to an exquisite resolution of 0.2" equivalent to ~kpc-scales at those redshifts. All targets are normal 'main sequence' galaxies that show thick disks co-rotating with massive clumps of star-formation. These clumps have typical star-formation rates that are ~15x higher than that seen in local HII regions. The combination of ALMA and the available IFU-AO data provides a unique and novel approach to decribe the star-formation rate using two gold-standard tracers at matched ~0.2" resolution in high-z galaxies. Mapping the dust with ALMA is key to constrain the extincion suffered by the star-light, i.e. critical to account for the obscured star-formation activity. High resolution ALMA observations for this new AO-aided sample are key to provide a decisive argument on the nature of the clumpy structures, therefore essential to understand how star-formation is being triggered at high-z.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00026.S: "A resolved view to the dust content in star-forming Halpha galaxies at z = 1.47-2.23" P.I.: E. Ibar 2015.1.00194.S: "The resolved view to the molecular gas content in a normal clumpy-disk galaxy at z = 1.46" P.I.: J. Molina
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00402.S: "Exploiting the synergy between early ALMA and VLT/AO-IFU" P.I.: E. Ibar 2013.1.00530.S: "A resolved view to star-forming Halpha galaxies at z=1.47-2.23: exploiting the synergy between ALMA and AO-IFU" P.I.:E. Ibar
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
